update.description:
This is a proof-of-concept for how to run a test against different plugins that implement the required features. I chose `SimulationFeatures_TEST.cc` as an example since it doesn't require any dart-specific features. We can consider moving this test to `test/integration` or something, but I refrained from doing that here so the diff is viewable.

* 5b08799: start by parameterizing the physics plugin library location in `SimulationFeatures_TEST.cc` to prepare for repeating the test over different plugins

* 8b0e909: create a global vector of plugin locations in a header file and run physics test for each physics plugin. This depends on the `dartsim_plugin_LIB` macro being defined in a cmake `add_definitions` call. I added a placeholder for `bullet_plugin_LIB` that results in a blank line in the header file for now.
update.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

content.html:
compiler warnings could be fixed by the following I think

diff -r 93d441f391d9 src/FindFeatures_TEST.cc
--- a/src/FindFeatures_TEST.cc  Fri Oct 12 13:05:49 2018 +0800
+++ b/src/FindFeatures_TEST.cc  Thu Oct 11 22:19:38 2018 -0700
@@ -72,7 +72,9 @@
   for (const std::string &acceptable : knownAcceptablePlugins)
   {
     if (allPlugins.count(acceptable) > 0)
-      EXPECT_EQ(1, foundPlugins.count(acceptable));
+    {
+      EXPECT_EQ(1u, foundPlugins.count(acceptable));
+    }
   }
 }

content.raw:
You probably noticed this already, but the `SimulationFeatures_TEST.cc` is located in `dartsim/src/`, so it only gets built when the `dartsim` component is built \(i.e. when `libdartsim` is available at configuration time\).

We'll probably want to move it into `test/integration` so that it's not dependent on `dartsim`.
content.html:
You probably noticed this already, but the SimulationFeatures_TEST.cc is located in dartsim/src/, so it only gets built when the dartsim component is built (i.e. when libdartsim is available at configuration time).

We'll probably want to move it into test/integration so that it's not dependent on dartsim.

pull_request.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

pullrequest.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

content.raw:
To address the current situation more directly:

> That's probably easier in the short-term than extending the `ignition::plugin::Loader::PluginsImplementing` to handle variadic template parameters.

A variadic `PluginsImplementing<...>()` would be very easy to write; the only trouble is that I promised a feature freeze on `ign-plugin`. If we’re willing to relax the feature freeze, this modification would be no trouble at all.

On the other hand, it also wouldn't be any trouble to wrap up the `PluginsImplementing<T>()` function in a variadic function that will find a plugin that satisfies every feature. I’ll take a stab at writing this function.
content.html:
To address the current situation more directly:

That's probably easier in the short-term than extending the ignition::plugin::Loader::PluginsImplementing to handle variadic template parameters.

A variadic PluginsImplementing<...>() would be very easy to write; the only trouble is that I promised a feature freeze on ign-plugin. If we’re willing to relax the feature freeze, this modification would be no trouble at all.

On the other hand, it also wouldn't be any trouble to wrap up the PluginsImplementing<T>() function in a variadic function that will find a plugin that satisfies every feature. I’ll take a stab at writing this function.

pull_request.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

pullrequest.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

content.raw:
When time allows, I’d still like to implement the “Behavior System” testing framework that I had described in the design document. \(Short version: instead of writing tests in the traditional way, we create plugin-agnostic tests based around the feature system. The tests would encode the types of behaviors that we expect when a feature gets used. These tests are exported as classes that downstream plugins can use as unit and integration tests, and to make sure that they conform to the expectations of Gazebo users.\)

That should eliminate this type of plugin selection issue altogether, because the plugins will choose the tests instead of the tests needing to choose the plugins.

But that’ll require design and implementation of a framework on the same level of sophistication as the feature system, so I’ll have to defer on that until there’s a little more wiggle-room in my development time. Fortunately it should be fine to move forward on writing these tests, and then refactoring them later once the behavior system is ready.
content.html:
When time allows, I’d still like to implement the “Behavior System” testing framework that I had described in the design document. (Short version: instead of writing tests in the traditional way, we create plugin-agnostic tests based around the feature system. The tests would encode the types of behaviors that we expect when a feature gets used. These tests are exported as classes that downstream plugins can use as unit and integration tests, and to make sure that they conform to the expectations of Gazebo users.)

That should eliminate this type of plugin selection issue altogether, because the plugins will choose the tests instead of the tests needing to choose the plugins.

But that’ll require design and implementation of a framework on the same level of sophistication as the feature system, so I’ll have to defer on that until there’s a little more wiggle-room in my development time. Fortunately it should be fine to move forward on writing these tests, and then refactoring them later once the behavior system is ready.

pull_request.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

pullrequest.title: [WIP] Run test against multiple physics plugins

content.raw:
This line is still a problem with the `ignition::physics::dartsim::Plugin` name hard-coded. I would love to use `Loader::PluginsImplementing`, but that only takes a single template parameter, but these physics plugins have a bunch of interfaces stuck together in a tuple.

We could load all plugins in each library file and call `RequestEngine` on each one to see if it has the features we need I suppose. That's probably easier in the short-term than extending the `ignition::plugin::Loader::PluginsImplementing` to handle variadic template parameters.
content.html:
This line is still a problem with the ignition::physics::dartsim::Plugin name hard-coded. I would love to use Loader::PluginsImplementing, but that only takes a single template parameter, but these physics plugins have a bunch of interfaces stuck together in a tuple.

We could load all plugins in each library file and call RequestEngine on each one to see if it has the features we need I suppose. That's probably easier in the short-term than extending the ignition::plugin::Loader::PluginsImplementing to handle variadic template parameters.
